dataType.hinttext: Enter ticket ID of resolved event

rule.title: Max Length
rule.customMessage: Value should be less than 7 characters and numbers

rule.title: Min Length
rule.customMessage: Value should be greater than 5 characters or numbers

label.id: Enter resolution and problem category in ticket
notify incident response team and customer

labelMapping.labelId: Enter resolution and problem category in ticket
notify incident response team and customer

group.description: Process of creating an initial incident ticket

custom.graphDetails: Customer reports an event to Help Desk. Help Desk creates a ticket that captures the event, event source, initial event severity and event priority. The ticket system creates a unique ID for the event. A first level responder is assigned ownership to the ticket. The first level responder captures additional event data and performs preliminary analysis in order to determine criticality of the event. At this level, it is either a Normal or an Escalation event. Normal events do not affect critical production systems or require change controls prior to the implementation of a resolution. Escalation events that affect critical production systems or require change controls must be escalated. Organization management may request an immediate escalation without first level review – second tier respondent will create ticket. The event is resolved and the ticket owner enters resolution and problem category into ticket. The customer receives the resolution for the ticket and confirms if the resolution is satisfactory. If confirmation is received, the ticket is closed by the ticket owner. If reporting entity evaluate the resolution as non-satisfactory, the escalation report is updated to show this event and ticket is escalated. If no confirmation is received within 1 month then ticket is closed.The ticket is assigned a second tier respondent to investigate the event. second tier respondent perform additional analysis and re-evaluates the criticality of the ticket. If necessary, the second tier respondent is responsible for escalating the ticket to emergency response and notifying both the incident response team and the customer. Emergency Response:Events may follow the escalation chain until it is determined that an emergency response is necessary.Top-level organization management may determine that an emergency response is necessary and invoke this process directly.

highlightLayers.highlightLayer:
Customer reports an event to Help Desk.
Help Desk creates a ticket that captures the event, event source, initial event severity and event priority. The ticket system creates a unique ID for the event.
A first level responder is assigned ownership to the ticket. The first level responder captures additional event data and performs preliminary analysis in order to determine criticality of the event. At this level, it is either a Normal or an Escalation event.
Normal events do not affect critical production systems or require change controls prior to the implementation of a resolution.
Escalation events that affect critical production systems or require change controls must be escalated.
Organization management may request an immediate escalation without first level review – second tier respondent will create ticket.
The event is resolved and the ticket owner enters resolution and problem category into ticket.
The customer receives the resolution for the ticket and confirms if the resolution is satisfactory. If confirmation is received, the ticket is closed by the ticket owner. If reporting entity evaluate the resolution as non-satisfactory, the escalation report is updated to show this event and ticket is escalated. If no confirmation is received within 1 month then ticket is closed.
The ticket is assigned a second tier respondent to investigate the event.
second tier respondent perform additional analysis and re-evaluates the criticality of the ticket. If necessary, the second tier respondent is responsible for escalating the ticket to emergency response and notifying both the incident response team and the customer.
Emergency Response: Events may follow the escalation chain until it is determined that an emergency response is necessary. Top-level organization management may determine that an emergency response is necessary and invoke this process directly.
